Award.AwardTitle: IRFP: Enriching 3D WebGIS Functionality to Study Ancient Human-Environment Interaction
Award.AbstractNarration:
The International Research Fellowship Program enables U.S. scientists and engineers to conduct nine to twenty-four months of research abroad. The program's awards provide opportunities for joint research, and the use of unique or complementary facilities, expertise and experimental conditions abroad.

This award will support a twenty-month research fellowship for Dr. Heather Richards-Rissetto to work with Dr. Fabio Remondino at the 3D Optical Metrology (3DOM) Research Unit at the Bruno Kessler Foundation (FBK) in Trento, Italy.

Current Information Technology (IT) and software capabilities are ready to move beyond simple 3D recording and visualization, but new 3D analytical tools making use of recent technological advances have not yet been developed. This project explores potentially transformative technologies and actively links the fields of 3D Modeling and Geographic Information Systems (GIS) by creating and testing new analytical tools for 3D Web GIS environments. The case study uses these new 3D Web GIS tools to analyze cultural and ecological variables to investigate ancient human-environment interaction at the UNESCO World Heritage Site of Copan, Honduras.

The project objectives are threefold. The first objective is to create analytical tools for 3D Web GIS that enable users to link, query, and analyze GIS data via a navigable virtual reality (VR) environment. Such functionality allows for complex spatial analysis in a VR environment--something that is not possible using currently available tools. The second objective is to use the new tools to study ancient human-environment interaction. The third objective is to disseminate these tools to a diverse audience for research and education purposes.

The technology underlying these new analytical tools can be used to develop additional 3D Web GIS tools that can significantly enhance research in many disciplines. Moreover, the theoretical and analytical results from the case study at Copan will enrich our understanding of the complexities of human-environment interaction. This knowledge can be applied to problems facing present-day and future populations.

The new 3D Web GIS tools developed in this project to study ancient human-environment interaction will promote research and education and are highly-suited to today's youth--visual learners who are intrigued, excited, and proficient in using interactive and dynamic technologies. The online capability of these tools allow people from underrepresented groups such as those living in developing countries to experience and participate in the study of a UNESCO World Heritage site. In addition, the project will help to establish international collaborations between the Principal Investigator (PI), the MayaArch3D Project based at the University of New Mexico, and researchers from diverse fields including information technology, geography, archaeology, photogrammetry, and the humanities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Current Information Technology (IT) and software capabilities are ready to move beyond simple 3D recording and visualization. This project made use of recent technological advances to develop a 3D WebGIS with analytical tools to study anthropomorphic landscapes. The tool’s open source framework can be applied to tool development in diverse fields. The project results and ongoing work have broad implications for many fields that benefit from visualizing and analyzing 2D and 3D data in a georeferenced (spatially referenced to real world) spatiotemporal context. Because the tool is web-based and designed to deal with hardware, software, and bandwidth limitations, it fosters the circulation and comparison of ideas including audiences and participants from developing countries.

The 3D WebGIS brings the spatial capabilities of GIS into a 3D environment more closely attuned to human perception.  It bridges the humanities and information technology in an innovative and ambitious way—providing researchers and educators with new ways to study social interaction, aesthetic experiences, relationships between people and built environment and natural landscape, indigenous concepts and more. The 3D WebGIS promotes research and education because it is highly-suited to today’s youth—visual learners who are intrigued, excited, and proficient in using interactive and dynamic technologies.

In regard to studying and understanding human-environment interaction the tool’s ability to link, query, and analyze objects and phenomena across multiple scales in a 3D environment allows people to "see" things that the flat, 2D perspective does not. Because  the tool uses georeferenced data and models, we have the ability to interchange variables and then visualize these variables in relation to their 3D physical surroundings. Bringing together settlement data with natural features (terrain, hydrology, etc.) allows researchers to test alternative scenarios for human-environmental interaction. Such capabilities are useful for studying human interactions with each other and their environment in the past, the present, and modeling for the future. The 3D WebGIS can be modified for applications in urban and community planning or environmental studies; thus, it can have far-reaching significance for studying the complexities of human-environment problems that face present-day and future populations.

Using the 3D WebGIS researchers and students move through a virtual landscape and query and interact with 3D models of objects and their associated data. Some advantages include: (1) access to virtual artefacts when original artefacts cannot be transported or handled, (2) offering a sense of mass and space for inaccessible landscapes (past or present), (3) comparisons of empirical data and hypothetical reconstructions,(4) metric and quantitative analysis, and (5) integration of qualitative and quantitative data via clickable 3D models that call up text, photographs, maps, or videos to create comprehensive datasets that facilitate new discoveries and knowledge.

The 3D WebGIS offers two interaction types: (1) device-based with keyboard and mouse and (2) gesture-based system using Microsoft’s Kinect that can be used to create a virtual heritage exhibit to engage the public in cultural heritage and foster respect for cultural diversity. The system is low-cost and portable and can easily be set-up in classrooms, community centers, or museums. The system offers a sense of embodiment in architecture or landscape (sense of place), and increases awareness of spatial relationships between objects and associated data, and helps the public to better understand empirical methods of how researchers analyze variables and relate findings (patterns) to human environment phenomena.
